With strike rates and success rates soaring to 80â€“90%, and anti-incumbency seemingly absent, allegations of electoral malpractice are growing sharper. Meanwhile, the NDA counters by asking: if you donâ€™t work, how do you expect to win?

Both parties contested 101 seats each.

On the other side, the Lok Janshakti Party is leading on 19 seats, while the RJDâ€™s performance is unfortunately stuck around the 50-seat markâ€”managing to lead in only about 25 constituencies. The Congressâ€™s performance is even worse percentage-wiseâ€”leading on just five seats as we record this episode.

Some who blame vote theft are, in fact, toying with the very fabric of Indian democracy. While allegations of electoral malpractice are not baseless, attributing the *entire* loss to it amounts to intellectual and moral dishonesty.

- Voter deletion
- Voter addition
- Fake votes enabling mass voting
- Voter suppressionâ€”preventing voters from reaching booths
- Strong booth-level influence (Panna Pramukhs)
- Counting irregularitiesâ€”delayed or unreleased numbers, gender-wise data not published
- Attempts to delete CCTV footage
- The SIR (Suo Motu Intervention by the Supreme Court) matter is still pending

## ğŸ¤” But Is Vote Theft the Whole Story?

Pragmatically speaking: Can vote theft alone explain why the Congress is leading on only 5 out of 61 seats? Has it become so potent that pressing one button changes everything? In our understanding, if you engage in large-scale voter deletion, addition, or manipulation, you cannot hide it. These activities happen in small amounts, scattered across regions.

There must be other reasons why the Congress fell from 61 to 5, and the RJD is struggling around 50.

## ğŸ’° The â‚¹10,000 Factor

The â‚¹10,000 transferâ€”though not strictly â€œvote theftâ€â€”is a form of bribery that significantly impacted the Bihar elections. Whether this was a rumor or a deliberately planted one, it likely contributed to higher womenâ€™s turnout. In the age of WhatsApp University, such tactics are entirely possible.

Special trains were also arrangedâ€”using government machineryâ€”to help supporters return home to vote. It was clear who was traveling, and for what purpose.

## ğŸ›‘ So, Should We Just Give Up?

Does this mean we should stop participating in elections? Should we sit back, salute our supreme leader like Kim Jong-un, and chant â€œDemocracy Zindabadâ€?

No. Because alongside vote theft, there is **work theft**â€”and we must place greater emphasis on the latter, because **hard work can defeat vote theft**.

Yes, vote theft can swing results by 4â€“5%â€”and in close elections, thatâ€™s serious. But in this case, the scale of work theft, lack of understanding, and broken public contact by the opposition also played a role.

Take Rahul Gandhi. In the last two months, he took two international trips. As election results pour in, nobody knows where he is. If heâ€™s a private citizen or an MP on a personal tripâ€”fine. But as the **Leader of the Opposition**, his absence during the Bihar elections sends a terribly negative message.

Even where Rahul Gandhi did campaign, the JD(U) and BJP are leading. This suggests that whatever little pull he hadâ€”gained from the Bharat Jodo Yatraâ€”is also fading. Rahul Gandhi needs to reinvent himself.

The answer lies not with Nitish or the BJPâ€”but with the RJD. The **fear of Jungle Raj** remains deeply embedded in peopleâ€™s minds. The BJP skillfully revived this fear, suggesting that if the RJD returned, the days of lawlessness would come back.

Tejashwi Yadavâ€™s weakness was his failure to actively build a **new RJD**â€”distancing himself from the old guard and his familyâ€”to show that the RJD was now a disciplined party with no connection to Jungle Raj.

That was work theft on the RJDâ€™s part. Tejashwi had momentum, but he failed to build on it.

## ğŸ§­ Lack of Vision

Neither Tejashwi nor Rahul Gandhi presented a **grand vision**. They criticized Nitish, they criticized the BJPâ€”but they offered no alternative. When people donâ€™t see a reason to support someone else, they happily take â‚¹10,000 and move on.

The â‚¹10,000 strategy isnâ€™t new. Shivraj Singh Chouhan in MP discovered long ago that if you give women benefits, you lock in their vote. The same happened in Maharashtra. The Congress has also used such tacticsâ€”but the BJP has taken it to the next level, framing it as just the beginning of a larger empowerment scheme.

---

## ğŸ—³ï¸ Booth-Level Strategy & Leadership Presence

Narendra Modi himself works on booth-level strategy in Biharâ€”speaking with Panna Pramukhs directly. Can you show me where the Congress or Tejashwi worked on booth-level strategy?

Amit Shah set a record for the most rallies addressed after nomination withdrawals. Top leaders were brought in for one month of intense campaigning under â€œMission Bihar.â€ This creates top-of-mind awarenessâ€”people feel the party is everywhere.

Meanwhile, Congress leaders werenâ€™t even in the countryâ€”let alone in Bihar.

---

## âœ… The Winning Combination

The BJP correctly assessed:
- We have organizational strength
- We donâ€™t have a CM face
- Nitish has immense emotional equity

So they didnâ€™t disturb the Nitish face, combined it with BJPâ€™s machinery and mightâ€”and got this massive result.

---

## ğŸ§­ The Way Forward for the Opposition

If vote theft is happening at some level, you have two choices:
1. Sit back and blame the Election Commissionâ€”and stop contesting elections altogether.
2. Enter the field and fight.

The Congress must accept that vote theft is realâ€”and work at the ground level to stop it. They must:
- Establish Panna Pramukhs
- Monitor booths to ensure fair voting
- Help those affected by vote theft get their rights

They must also bring **alliance discipline**. The circus of bringing in someone like Krupal Aluruâ€”who doesnâ€™t know Biharâ€”thinking heâ€™ll win because he runs a wedding portal, is unacceptable. By the end, even the Congress seemed to realize this and sidelined him.

The childish tug-of-war over whether Tejashwi was the CM face should have been sorted months before the election.

---

## ğŸ§  Messaging & Modeling

You may like or dislike Narendra Modiâ€”but the opposition needs a **message**, a **model**, and an **emotional pitch** for the country. Where is it?

Candidate credibility matters. You need to be in the party high commandâ€™s good books. If Rahul Gandhi or the Gandhis donâ€™t like you, youâ€™re finished. This culture must change. Performance must be rewarded.

Questions are already being raised: Rahul Gandhi has now headed nearly 100 electionsâ€”and lost them. In any other party or country, such a leader would have stepped aside. But here, the debate just goes onâ€”and if you raise it, the Congress IT cell gets angry.

The Congress must understand: it needs to allow new leaders, take risks, and move forward. Otherwise, India will truly become a one-party democracy.

---

## ğŸ›‘ Secret International Tripsâ€”Please Stop

These childish antics must end. You are not a private citizen. You are the most visible official Leader of the Opposition. You donâ€™t have the right to slip away on private visits secretly. The BJP didnâ€™t exploit this as much as they could haveâ€”but it will be used against you in the future.

---

## ğŸ”® Whatâ€™s Next?

Upcoming elections in UP and Bengal are crucial. How will the opposition behave? Will the Congress follow its ego? Will it support other parties? Will votes split? Or will the Congress fall below even regional parties?

One thing is clear: both vote theft and the Congressâ€™s lack of professionalism are responsible for this electoral outcome. Both must be addressed. If you just blame vote theft and sit back, more results like this will follow.
